title: Terrorists and paedophiles too dangerous to be freed may be given DOLE because they can't get jobs
text:
Some of Australia's most notorious criminals are set to be given the dole because they're too dangerous to be let free even after their jail terms are up.

Under a new scheme, Victoria's most dangerous offenders - including terrorists and paedophiles - will be sent to a detention centre when have served their sentences.

Because they are no longer prisoners but cannot be freed into the wider community, they are likely to be eligible for dole payments while staying at the new 10-bed Piper Detention Unit at the Barwon Prison.

A detention unit at Barwon Prison. designed to house Victoria's most dangerous offenders after they have finished their sentences, has been opened and detainees could receive the dole

The $21 million unit will house serious sex and violent offenders who have finished their prison terms but are deemed to pose an unacceptable risk of reoffending if released.

Serious sex and violent offenders can be detained by the Supreme Court for a maximum period of three years with an option to renew.

The Department of Social Services confirmed to The Herald Sun a released prisoner, even one in detention, can receive the dole if they meet eligibility criteria.

One of the first prisoners expected to be house in the complex is terror mastermind Abdul Nacer Benbrika.

Benbrik's sentence for planning a terrorist act is set to end next year but under federal legislation he is expected to be kept in detention.

Minister for Corrections Ben Carroll said the new detention unit was the first step towards overhauling the prison release system for dangerous criminals.

'This is about helping protect Victorians from the most serious sex and violent offenders who pose an unacceptable risk of reoffending – even after they have completed their sentence,' he said.

'These are nation-leading reforms that are about managing our most serious offenders in a safe environment.'

The Department of Social Services, which administers Centrelink payments confirmed a released prisoner, even one in detention, can receive the dole if they meet eligibility criteria

The court must be satisfied the offender poses an unacceptable risk of causing further harm should they be released, and that risk cannot be managed on a supervision order.

Piper contains 10 individual rooms across four units, ensuring detainees can be separated for safety and security purposes.

Detainees will also have access to education and vocational training to help develop their skills and contribute to their rehabilitation.

Post-sentence detention is an integral part of the Harper Review into serious offenders.
description: Some of Australia's most notorious criminals are set to be given the dole because they're too dangerous to be let free even after their jail terms are up.
authors: Adam Mccleery For Daily Mail Australia
